Clinical features of UC:
-Similarity to {{c1::CD}}
-Variable (relapse and exacerbation)
-{{c1::mucoid}} diarrhea (sometimes {{c1::blood}} stained)
-massive {{c1::bleeding}} - characteristic of UC
-obstruction due to {{c1::toxic}} megacolon (has to be removed) or {{c1::cancer}}.

Complications of UC:
-{{c1::anemia}}
- massive {{c1::bleeding}}
- toxic {{c1::megacolon}} (may present with vomiting feces)
- {{c1::cancer}}

Treatment
1. medical
2. {{c1::surgical}}

Crohn's
-Surgery: if medicine has failed OR fistula formation OR cancer indication

UC:
-Surgery: if medicine has failed (success depends on stage of UC) OR massive bleeding OR toxic megacolon OR severe dysplasia/cancer

Extraintestinal manifestations (may present with these symptoms)
-poly{{c1::arthritis}}
-{{c1::ankylosing}} spodylitis
-erythema {{c1::nodosum}}
-primary sclerosing {{c1::cholangitis}}
-{{c1::uveitis}}

-Crohn's starts in GIT but..complains of joint pain, erythema, lower back pain, inflammation in GB, etc.
-Autoimmune disease - systemic disease but usually starts with one organ


-polyarthritis: at least 5 joints are affected with arthritis
-ankylosing spondylitis - long term condition where the spine and other areas of body become inflammed
-erythema nodosum - type of panniculitis - inflammatory disorder affecting subcut fat
-primary sclerosing cholangitis - inflammation causes scars within the bile ducts

An obstruction in Crohn's is due to {{c1::fibrosis}} while an obstruction in UC is due to {{c1::toxic megacolon}} (inflammatory neutrophils secrete radicals causing colon muscle to become paralyzed).
Toxic megacolon - Has to be removed

Benign tumours involve:
-{{c1::adenomas}}
-{{c1:: leiomyoma}}
-{{c1::schwanomma}}

Malignant tumours
2 main ones:
-{{c1::Squamous carcinoma}} (oesophagus)
-{{c1::adenocarcinoma}}
Rest:
-{{c1::small}} cell carcinoma (uncommon but aggressive)
-lymphoma
-{{c1::endocrine}} tumours (low grade malignant potential)
-{{c1::GI Stromal}} tumours (GIST) (mesenchymal tissue on stomach wall)
-{{c1::Kaposis}} sarcoma (immune deficiency - vascular tumour)

Oesophageal Cancer
-{{c1::Squamous (SCC)}} cell carcinoma is the commonest oeso tumour worldwide.
-{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}} has had an increased incidence in the last 2 decades - now approaching SCC - up to {{c1::50}}% of all oeso carcinoma in US
-{{c1::Small}} cell carcinoma is uncommon
Squamous and adenocarcinoma differ in risk factors and site of disease.

Oesophageal squamous cell carcinoma risk factors:
-{{c1::Nitrates}} and nitrosamines
-{{c1::tobacco}} smoke
-{{c1::alcohol}}
-{{c1::vitamin}} deficiencies
-{{c1::achalasia}} (motility disorder of oesophagus)
-strictures
-HPV

premalignant - dysplasia (low and high grade)
-adjacent to invasive SCC in 60-90% of cases
*low grade - high grade - invasive pathway

Oesophageal SCC - macroscopic
-Affects the upper oesophagus {{c1::10-20}}%, mid esophagus, {{c1::50-60}}%, or lower esophagus {{c1::30}}%.
-Luminal growth obstruction due to the tumour can cause {{c1::dysphagia}} and {{c1::weight}} loss.
-Characterisitcs are {{c1::ulcerating}}, infiltrating, and {{c1::poly}}ploid

Oesophageal SCC - microscopic
-{{c1::Dysplastic}} squamous epithelium 
-Invades {{c1::submucosa}} and deeper
= +/- {{c1::keratinisation}}, intercellular {{c1::bridges}}
-{{c1::poorly}} differentiated sheets of cells
-carcino{{c1::sarcoma}}
carincosarcoma = carincoma (squamous epithelium) + sarcoma

Oesophageal adenocarcinoma
-almost all develop in association with pre-existing {{c1::Barretts oesophagus}}.
-Associated with gastroesophageal {{c1::reflux}} in the {{c1::distal}} oesophagus.
-6-12% of patients with GE {{c1::reflux}} develop Barretts.
-0.5 to 1% per year of patients with Barretts will develop {{c1::adenocarcinoma}}.

Barretts Oesophagus/metaplasia
-Normal {{c1::squamous}} lined epithelium replaced by {{c1::columnar}} epithelium.
-Due to chronic GE {{c1::reflux}}
-Metaplasia
-Most easily recognised - {{c1::goblet}} cells (intestinal) present
HALLMARK

Barretts oesophagus has a risk associated with {{c1::dysplasia}}.
-Low grade - involves crowding, {{c1::basal}} nuclei - 3 year surveillance.
-High grade - {{c1::stratified}} nuclei, {{c1::pleo}}morphism, {{c1::mitoses}}  to surface - {{c1::yearly}} follow up after surgery.
-Nodule, {{c1::ulcer}}, and HG - {{c1::40}}% risk of adjacent ca.

Identifying dysplasia is a challenge in Barretts oesophagus.
-Inter-observer {{c1::variation::variation/agreement}} in low grade dysplasia.
-inter-observer {{c1::agreement::variation/agreement}} in high grade dysplasia.
-{{c1::p53}} marker increased expression in most cases of dysplasia.
brown-p53

oesophageal adenocarcinoma
-macroscopic: {{c1::ulcer}}, mass, +/- extends across {{c1::gastropesophageal}} junction
-microscopic - invasive malignant {{c1::glands}}.
may not see background barretts

oesophageal carcinoma prognosis
- invasion through {{c1::oesophagus}} wall - trachea, {{c1::aorta}}, pericardium.
-{{c1::60}}% have lymph node metastases at presentation
-overall {{c1::5}} year survival is 30-40% higher in those with {{c1::early}} (less invasive) disease and node {{c1::negative}}.
-Most adenocarcinomas have invaded {{c1::muscularis propria}} at presentation. {{c1::10-20}}% 5 year survival.

The commonest tumour of gastric cancer is gastric {{c1::adenocarcinoma}}. The second commonest cancer in world with 800K new cases per year (650K deaths). Decreased incidence associated with:
-decreased {{c1::salt}} intake
-decreased {{c1::salt}} for fish/{{c1::meat}} preservation
-increased {{c1::fresh fruit}}/veg in diet
Increased advances in early detection in {{c1::high}} incidence areas.

Gastric adenocarcinoma
-High incidence (>40/100000 M pop) in East {{c1::Asia}}, {{c1::Andes}} regions of S. America, {{c1::East}} Europe
-Low incidence (<15/100000 M pop) in N. America, {{c1::North}} Europe, Most of {{c1::Africa}}, and {{c1::Southeast}} Asia.

20-fold difference between the high to low incidence areas.

Etiology of gastric adenocarcinoma includes 
-{{c1::diet}}
-{{c1::Bile}} reflux
-{{c1::H.Pylori}}
-{{c1::Oxidative}} stress
-interference with anti-{{c1::oxidant}} function
-{{c1::DNA}} damage (point mutations).

Gastric adenocarcinoma and diet
High risk
-{{c1::Salt}}
-{{c1::Smoked}}/Cured meat/{{c1::fish}}
-{{c1::pickled}} vegetables
-{{c1::chilli}} peppers
Low Risk
-{{c1::fruit}}/{{c1::veggies}}

Gastric adenocarcinoma and diet
-benefits of fruit and veg: {{c1::antioxidant}} effect. Key protective agents: {{c1::ascorbic}} acid, {{c1::carotenoids}}, folate.
-role unclear: {{c1::alcohol}}, nitrosamines, tobacco.

{{c1::H.Pylori}} is a rod shaped organism that lives in mucus over gastric epithelium. Most frequent cause of {{c1::chronic gastritis}}. It is associated with gastric {{c1::adenocarcinoma}} and lymphoma.

H.Pylori
Causes and results:
1. Chronic {{c1::Gastritis}} - intestinal {{c1::metaplasia}}
2. Decreased {{c1::acid}} secretion - increased {{c1::pH}} (nitrosated products - carcinogens)
3. Decreased intra gastric {{c1::ascorbic acid}} - loss of {{c1::antioxidant}} AA (increased oxidants)
4. Increased {{c1::oxidants}} - DNA {{c1::point}} mutations

Gastric adenocarcinoma symptoms and signs
- often very {{c1::late}} in presentation (80-90% in low incidence countries)

-Early - 50% will have non-specific {{c1::dyspepsia}}

-Late - persistent abdominal {{c1::pain}}
  - unrelieved by {{c1::eating}}
  - {{c1::bleeding}} (ulceration) - hematemesis
  - Gastric outlet {{c1::obstruction}}
  - {{c1::Anorexia}} and {{c1::weight}} loss         
    (disseminated disease)

{{c1::Endoscopy}} and {{c1::biopsy}} are used to diagnose gastric adenocarcinoma.
-Early gastric cancer - presents with a slight change in mucosa {{c1::colour}} and {{c1::architecture.}}
-Advanced cancer is an obvious {{c1::lesion}}
-{{c1::barium}} meal is used as part of mass screening in some countries followed by {{c1::endoscopy}} if abnormality detected.

{{c1::Early Gastric Cancer}} is carcinoma confined to the mucosa or to mucosa and submucosa regardless of LN status. Aim of screening programmes is to detect {{c1::EGC}} in {{c1::high}} risk areas. In screening areas - 80% of cancers detected are {{c1::EGC}}. In low incidence areas - 80-90% of cancers are {{c1::advanced}} at presentation.

Gastric adenocarcinoma macroscopic appearance
-commonest site is the {{c1::distal}} stomach (antro-pyloric region)
-next commonest is the {{c1::body}} of the stomach - {{c1::greater}} or {{c1::lesser}} curve.

Macroscopic appearances involve:
-elevated {{c1::lesion}}
-poly{{c1::poid}}
-{{c1::ulcer}}
-diffuse infiltrative {{c1::linitis plastica}} (leather stomach)

Microscopic appearances of gastric cancer involve:
-{{c1::intestinal}} type
-{{c1::mucinous}} (extracellular mucin)
-{{c1::papillary}}
-{{c1::signet}} rings

This is an image of intestinal {{c1::metaplasia}} - carcinoma sequence.


This is an image of {{c1::signet ring}} carcinoma

Precursor lesions of gastric adenocarcinoma involve 
-{{c1::gastritis}} (chronic H.Pylori, autoimmune)
-intraepithelial {{c1::neoplasia}}
-adenoma
-{{c1::polyps}}

Gastric Dysplasia

-Low grade dysplasia has some mild {{c1::crowding}} and some nuclear {{c1::atypia}}.

-High grade dysplasia - marked cell crowding, nuclear {{c1::pleomorphism}}, {{c1::stratification}}.

1. {{c1::10}}%
2.{{c1::carcinoma}}
3. {{c1::hyperplastic}}
4. {{c1::neoplastic}}
5. {{c1::Polyposis}}

Gastric {{c1::Adenomas}} make up 10% of all gastric polyps. They are circumscribed {{c1::benign}} lesions.
-Involves both low and high grade {{c1::dysplasia}}
-<2cm 2% risk of {{c1::malignant}} transformation
->2cm 40-50% {{c1::malignant}} transformation

Gastric neoplasia

{{c1::Intraepithelial}} neoplasia = confined to surface epithelium (dysplasia, low and high grade) e.g. adenoma
{{c1::Intramucosal}} carcinoma = invasion of lamina propria
{{c1::Early Gastric}} cancer = carcinoma confined to mucosa or into submucosa
{{c1::Advanced Gastric}} cancer  = invasion deeper than submucosa

Molecular genetics of gastic carinoma

{{c1::Majority::majority/minority}} of gastric cancer is sporadic.
-{{c1::10}}% have an inherited familial component. Family clustering with a {{c1::dominant}} inheritance pattern.
- studies suggest a small increased risk of gastric cancer in {{c1::first}} degree relatives
-hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (e-cadherin)
-gastric cancer as part of hereditary {{c1::nonpolyposis colon::2 words}} cancer (HNPCC)
-rarely gastric cancer in {{c1::Peutz Jeghers}} syndrome
-Blood group {{c1::A}} associated with gastric cancer.

Gastric carcinoma prognosis

-EGC with small mucosal lesions < 4cm with low incidence of vessel invasion - 10 year survival up to {{c1::90}}%
-EGC with vessel invasion - {{c1::65}}% 5 year survival
-Advanced Gastric cacncer - {{c1::TNM}} staging system - prognostic info
-LN positive 5 year survival {{c1::5-40}}%
-Diffuse carcinoma {{c1::poorer}} prognosis than intestinal subtype

Advances in treatment of oesophageal and gastric cancer

-{{c1::Neoadjuvant}} therapy - chemo and radiotherapy
-Oesophagus and Gastric - similar - {{c1::capcita}}bine, 5FU and {{c1::Cisplatin}}
-{{c1::MAGIC}} study - gastric
-{{c1::metal}} stent to improve
-surgical {{c1::excision}} - distal oesophagus and prox gastrectomy;gastrectomy/+/- distal gastrectomy
-post op chemotherapy

Gastroc/OG junction carcinoma and herceptin

-{{c1::ToGA}} trial - phase 3 randomized multicentre trial
- >3800 gastric ca
- {{c1::Trastuzumab}} (herceptin) assoc with reduced death risk (26%) and {{c1::survival}} benefit in advanced {{c1::HER2}} positive gastric cancer

Gastric lymphoma

{{c1::10}}% of all gastric cancers are lymphomas
-Non Hodgkins lymphoma - 2 main types
1. Low grade lymphomas arising from {{c1::mucosal associated lymphoid tissue}} in bowerl (MALT lymphomas)
2. High Grade {{c1::B cell NHL}} (majority): some of these will have evolved through progression of low grade lymphoma.

Gastric Lymphoma etiology

- low grade lymphomas, MALT lymphomas arising from mucosa associated lymphoid tissue in {{c1::stomach}} wall;
-{{c1::H.Pylori}} associated and regress with {{c1::H.Pylori}} eradication
-High grade diffuse large {{c1::B cell NHL}}
-Increased incidence of lymphoma with {{c1::immune}} deficiency also (e.g. AIDS)

Gastric lymphoma microscopic

-High grade - diffuse large B cell 
-Large cells infilitrate and destroy {{c1::glandular}} epithelium and invade deeply
-prominent {{c1::nucleoli}} and {{c1::chromatin}}
-may show {{c1::plasma}} cell differentiation

Gastric lymphoma outcome

-Low grade MALT lymphoma - regression on {{c1::H pylori}} eradication
-65-85% remission in these cases
-Takes {{c1::1-18}} months for remission
-Up to {{c1::10}}% relapse in 24 months (Study)
-Best outcome where MALT NGL confined to {{c1::mucosa}}/upper submucosa
-poorer outcome for HG and non {{c1::H Pylori}}
-Surgical {{c1::resection}} of NHL prolongs survival

Endocrine Tumours

1. {{c1::Carcinoid}} tumours
- Type 1 associated with {{c1::autoimune gastritis}}
-Type II associated with {{c1::MEN}} and {{c1::Zollinger Ellison}} Syndrome
-Type III is sporadic
2. {{c1::Small cell}} carcinoma - similar to locations elsewhere

Gastric carcinoid tumours

•Usually non {{c1::functioning}}
•Single or multiple
•>{{c1::10}}% of all GI carcinoids
•{{c1::F::F/M}}> {{c1::M::F/M}}   (2.5:1)
•Groups of closely packed cells, round nuclei, {{c1::granular}} cytoplasm

Gastro intestinal stromal tumour (GIST) of stomach
•Tumour of {{c1::mesenchyme}}
•Account for > {{c1::2}}% of all malignant gastric tumours
•Uncommon in oesophagus
•{{c1::Stomach}} is commonest GI site: 60-70% of GISTs occur in {{c1::stomach}}
•Macroscopic: {{c1::nodular}} mass- submucosal, intramural, subserosal, vary in size
•Submucosal lesions may ulcerate

Gastric GISTs microscopy
•{{c1::Spindle}} cell neoplasm +/- plumper cells
•Cells resemble smooth muscle but are negative with SM {{c1::actin}} stain
•Malignant behaviour determined by tumour {{c1::size}} and counting of {{c1::mitoses}}
•Malignant tumours can metastasise
•GISTs are positively staining with {{c1::KIT}} (CD117)-typical

Golden Rule - spindle cell lesions oeso and stomach

• Spindle cell lesion in {{c1::oesophagus}} likely to be a leiomyoma than GIST
•Spindle cell lesion in {{c1::stomach}} more likely to be a GIST than leiomyoma
•Must to CD117, SMA, etc on all

{{c1::Kaposis}} Sarcoma is a malignant tumour of blood vessels.
-It is seen in gastric mucosa (and in small intestine) in {{c1::immunsuppressed}} patients (HIV+).
-{{c1::Spindle}} cell lesion with {{c1::slit}} like vascular channels.

Secondary tumours oesophagus and stomach
•Very {{c1::uncommon::common/uncommon}}
•Direct spread- from {{c1::carcinoma}} of pancreas, oesophagus and gallbladder to {{c1::stomach}}
•Distant metastases from {{c1::breast}} carcinoma and melanoma
•Macro- may show mass {{c1::lesion}} or diffuse infiltration; +/- {{c1::pigmentation}} (melanoma)
•Micro- typical appearance of primary tumour
•Poor prognosis - indicate {{c1::late}} stage of tumour

Diabetes Mellitus:

A term for several diseases of abnormal {{c1::carbohydrate}} metabolism that are characterized by {{c1::hyperglycaemia}}.
Associated with relative or absolute impairment of insulin secretion by the islet cells of the {{c1::pancreas}}, along with varying degrees of peripheral resistance to the action of insulin.

Normal Carbohydrate Metabolism

•Blood glucose levels are normally maintained within a relatively narrow range ({{c1::4}}-{{c1::8}} mmol/L)
•This ensures that glucose is available as
–an {{c1::energy}} source (oxidised to H2O and CO2 yielding energy in the from of ATP)
–a precursor to complex {{c1::carbohydrates}}, proteins and {{c1::lipids}}
•On eating
–Complex carbohydrates are {{c1::hydrolysed}} to simple sugars (including glucose, fructose & galactose) that are absorbed through the small {{c1::intestine}} into the bloodstream.
–The rise in blood glucose stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.
–Insulin stimulates tissues to use the excess blood glucose:
•Activating glucose uptake into {{c1::muscle}} & adipose tissue
•Activating glycogen synthesis & inhibiting {{c1::glycogenolysis}} in muscle & liver cells
•Inhibiting gluconeogenesis
–Blood glucose levels fall

Normal Carbohydrate Metabolism

•Between meals
–As blood glucose levels fall insulin secretion by the pancreas slows and glucagon is released. The impact of this change to the hormonal milieu is:
–{{c1::Gluconeogenesis}} and glycogenolysis are activated to maintain blood glucose levels
•In prolonged fasting
–Lipids become an increasingly important energy source
–Fatty acids are released from adipose tissue ({{c1::lipolysis}}) and these can be used as an energy source by a variety of tissues (β-{{c1::oxidation}})
–Fatty acids cannot cross the blood brain barrier. When blood glucose levels are low, liver cells partially metabolise fatty acids releasing {{c1::ketone}} bodies into the bloodstream. {{c1::Ketone}} bodies can cross the blood brain barrier & can be taken up by brain cells as an energy source.

Deficiency/Resistance to Insulin

•Without insulin glucose is not taken up by muscle & adipose tissue
•{{c1::Glycogenolysis}} is activated in liver and muscle
•{{c1::Proteins}} are catabolised for energy & gluconeogenesis in many tissues
•Blood glucose levels rise
•Fatty acids are released into the bloodstream
–used as an energy source
–triglycerides resynthesized in {{c1::liver}} & repackaged into {{c1::lipoproteins}} (increased risk of atherosclerosis)
–Fatty acids are partially metabolised to ketone bodies that can be taken up as an energy source by brain cells

Symptoms associated with hyperglycaemia and glycosuria

•{{c1::Polyuria}}
–Filtered glucose exceeds tubular reabsorption threshold
–Osmotic diuresis created by glucose in urine
•{{c1::Polydipsia}}
–Combination of hyperglycaemia and water loss in urine result in plasma {{c1::hyperosmolality}}
–Hypertonicity is detected by specialised {{c1::hypothalamic}} cells (osmoreceptors). These osmoreceptors, along with angiotensin II, released secondary to volume depletion, stimulate thirst centres
•Weight loss
–Glycosuria and excess utilisation of {{c1::fat}} and protein as energy source
•Fatigue and hunger
–Inability of blood glucose to enter cells for {{c1::glycolysis}}

Diagnosing Diabetes Mellitus

Diagnosing diabetes mellitus is based on demonstrating hyperglycaemia through:
1. Diabetes {{c1::symptoms}} (polyuria, polydipsia and unexplained weight loss) plus:
a random {{c1::venous}} plasma glucose concentration > 11.1 mmol/L
  or
a fasting plasma glucose concentration > {{c1::7.0}} mmol/L
  or
plasma glucose concentration > {{c1::11.1}} mmol/L two hours after {{c1::75g}} anhydrous glucose in an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).
2. With no symptoms diagnosis requires elevated glucose levels on at least {{c1::two}} occasions
3. An HbA1c of >{{c1::48}} mmol/mol
Note: None of these tests are specific for type of diabetes. Type is usually established based on clinical presentation.

Plasma Glucose

•Plasma is blood minus the cellular constituents (e.g. red blood cells, white blood cells and {{c1::platelets}})
•Important pre-analytical issues in ensuring accurate plasma glucose levels
–Clarity on patient state (fasting, 2 hour post glucose load, random)
•Critical to document time and fasting state of patient for accurate interpretation
–Specimen tube must prevent blood clotting
•If a clot forms, it may be more difficult to get a clean separation of the cells from the plasma
•To prevent clotting the collection tubes we use contain {{c1::oxalate}} salts. {{c1::Oxalate}} prevents clotting by forming {{c1::insoluble}} complexes with the calcium in the blood which is required for clotting
–Specimen tube must prevent {{c1::glycolysis}}
•Blood cells will continue to metabolise glucose in vitro
•Blood tubes for measuring glucose contain sodium {{c1::fluoride}} to inhibit enzymes involved in {{c1::glycolysis}}.

Hb A1c

•Proteins are continuously undergoing non-enzymatic chemically modification by glucose ({{c1::glycation}})
–Results in advanced glycation products (AGE) which may contribute to {{c1::microvascular}} and macrovascular complications of diabetes
•Hb A1c is formed by the glycation of the N-terminal {{c1::valine}} residue of each {{c1::β}}-chain of Hb A with glucose
•Formation of Hb A1c is essentially {{c1::irreversible}}
•The concentration in the blood depends on the lifespan of the red blood cell (average 120 days) and the blood glucose concentration
•It therefore reflects the integrated value for blood glucose over the preceding 6-8 weeks

largely reflects glycaemic control.
Can be expressed as percentage or mmol/mol

HbA1c in diagnosis

•DCCT units for Hb A1c were given as a % of Hb that is glycated
•We now use IFCC units (mmol of Hb A1c per mol of Hb A)
•Hb A1c has been accepted as a diagnostic indicator of diabetes mellitus at >{{c1::48}} mmol/mol•Caution required with interpretation because of:
–Shortened {{c1::RBC}} lifespan could result in a ↓ Hb A1c
•{{c1::Haemolytic}} disease
•Recent significant blood loss
–Lengthened {{c1::RBC}} lifespan could result in a ↑ HbA1c
•{{c1::Iron}} deficiency anaemia
–Haemoglobin variants (e.g. Hb S, Hb F, Hb C) can interfere with RBC lifespan, Hb glycation & analytical methods
{{c1::Sickle cell trait}} can interfere with accuracies in measuring and diagnosing diabetes with HbA1C.

Glycosuria

•Glycosuria (or glucosuria) is excretion of glucose in the urine
•How diabetes (‘to pass through’) mellitus (‘honey-sweet’) got its name!
•Filtered glucose is normally reabsorbed in the {{c1::proximal}} renal tubule
•However, the renal threshold for glucose reabsorption is ~{{c1::10}} mmol/L & if blood glucose is higher than this, glucose will be present in the urine
•Testing for glycosuria is not an accepted way of diagnosing diabetes
–Not {{c1::sensitive}}
•moderate {{c1::hyperglycaemia}} may not result in glycosuria
–Not specific
•renal threshold for glucose reabsorption is {{c1::variable}}
•some people, especially {{c1::pregnant}} women and children, excrete glucose with relatively normal blood glucose

Diabetes Risk States

•Impaired Fasting Glycaemia/Glucose
–Fasting glucose {{c1::5}}.6-{{c1::7.0}} mmol/l
–Suggests {{c1::hepatic}} insulin resistance
–Associated with a markedly increased risk of developing type {{c1::II}} diabetes mellitus
•{{c1::Impaired}} Glucose Tolerance
–OGTT 2h glucose {{c1::7.8}}-11.0 mmol/l
–Suggests {{c1::muscle}} insulin resistance
–Not associated with increased risk of microvascular disease but at substantially increased risk of macrovascular disease
•As HbA1c climbs from 34 to 48 mmol/l the {{c1::5}} year risk of T2DM increases markedly

DM Classification

•Type I Diabetes Mellitus
–In Ireland ~15,000 cases
•Type II Diabetes Mellitus
–In Ireland ~210,000 cases
•Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY)
–2 to 5 percent of diabetes.
–Non-insulin dependent diabetes diagnosed at a young age (<25 years) with autosomal {{c1::dominant}} transmission and lack of auto-antibodies.
–Many patients are misclassified as having either type 1 or 2 diabetes.
•Diseases of the {{c1::Pancreas}}
–Cystic fibrosis, hereditary hemochromatosis, chronic pancreatitis,
•Endocrinopathies
–Cushing syndrome & acromegaly can lead to glucose dysregulation
•{{c1::Drug}}-induced diabetes
–A variety of drugs can impair glucose tolerance including corticosteroids, antipsychotics, immunosuppressants
•Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
–~2% of women develop a form of diabetes in pregnancy
–Increased risk of several adverse outcomes in pregnancy
•Pre-eclampsia, hydramnios, macrosomia, perinatal mortality, miscarriage, etc.
–Usually resolves post-{{c1::partum}} but mothers at increased risk of developing Type {{c1::II}} DM

T1DM Clinical Presentation

•Peak age is around {{c1::puberty}}, but it may present at any age
•The most common presentation is with clinical features associated with hyperglycaemia
–{{c1::Polyuria}}, {{c1::polydipsia}}, fatigue, hunger, weight loss, {{c1::blurred}} vision
•Timeframe
–Days, weeks or months
–Shorter in children, more insidious in adults
•Infection commonly {{c1::precipitates}} the initial presentation
–Fever, sore throat, cough, dysuria
•In practice, at diagnosis patients with T1DM commonly have glucose levels of {{c1::15}}-30 mmol/L and about 25% present with diabetic {{c1::ketoacidosis}}
•Results from the autoimmune destruction of the insulin-producing beta cells in the {{c1::pancreas}}.
•Antibodies are often detectable to:
–insulin - particularly in children
–{{c1::65}}-kD isoform of glutamic acid {{c1::decarboxylase}} (GAD65) - particularly in adults
–islet cells

Determinants & Risk Factors for T2DM

•{{c1::Genetics}} are a significant contributory factor
–Family history
–Ethnicity: Asians > Hispanics > Blacks > Whites
•Demographic characteristics
–Risk increases with age
–Females at higher risk than males
•Lifestyle
–Obesity (central adiposity), physical inactivity, smoking
–Too much or too little sleep
–Red meat, processed meat and sugary drinks are associated with an increased risk
–Fruits, vegetables, nuts, whole grains and olive oil are associated with a reduced risk
–Westernisation, urbanisation, modernisation
•Traditionally a disorder of aging but prevalence of obesity & T2DM in children is rising dramatically

Insulin Resistance

•An impaired biological response to insulin found in T2DM
•The pancreas makes insulin but the {{c1::tissues}} don’t respond as well to it
•Reduced insulin-stimulated glucose transport and metabolism in {{c1::adipocytes}} & skeletal {{c1::muscle}}
•Impaired {{c1::suppression}} of hepatic glucose output
•Insulin resistance is usually combined with some degree of {{c1::β}}-cell dysfunction in T2DM
•Pancreas ends up producing more insulin in order to get the same
•β-cell hyperplasia and {{c1::hypertrophy}} helps maintain normal glucose levels
•Over time the pancreas becomes {{c1::hypotrophic}} & hypoplastic & glucose levels rise because of lack of insulin produced by pancreas
•Diabetic {{c1::ketoacidosis}} usually doesn’t develop as there is some insulin which limits lipolysis

Differentiating between Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes

•No set criteria, but based on clinical presentation & history, sometimes supported by laboratory studies
•Body habitus
–Children with T1DM usually not obese & recent hx of weight loss
–T2DM usually, but not necessarily, obese
•Age
–T1DM usually present as children
–T2DM usually present later, but with obesity may present in childhood
•Insulin resistance
–T2DM frequently have acanthosis nigricans, {{c1::hypertension}}, {{c1::dyslipidemia}} and polycystic {{c1::ovary}} syndrome
•Family history
–{{c1::10}}% in T1DM
–Up to 75-90% in T2DM

•Laboratory Tests
–Auto-{{c1::antibodies}} an indicator of T1DM, but may be present in T2DM (?slowly progressive autoimmune disease)
–Higher fasting insulin & c-peptide levels in T2DM
–MODY
•Family History in keeping with autosomal dominant inheritance
•Genetic testing can be arranged
{{c1::Polyp}} is a descriptive term for a mass protruding into lumen.
Most neoplasms can present as polyps but not all polyps are neoplasms

{{c1::Neoplasm}}: A proliferation of cells that results from autonomous, excessive, unco-ordinated growth

{{c1::Adenoma}}: A benign (i.e. no metastatic potential) neoplastic growth of glandular tissue with dysplasia  

{{c1::Dysplasia}}: Abnormal cells that have malignant potential but not metastatic potential. In the colon, dysplasia may be low grade or high grade

{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}}: Invasive neoplastic growth arising within dysplastic glandular epithelium with metastatic potential

{{c1::Hamartoma}}: A mass that contains an abnormal arrangement of tissue that is native to the site. Can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic

Types of polyps in Colon

Epithelial (commonest)
–{{c1::Hyperplastic polyps}} (one of most common)
–Sessile serrated lesions
–{{c1::Adenomas}} (one of most common)
–Carcinomas
–Neuroendocrine tumours
•Non-epithelial
–{{c1::Lipomas}}
–{{c1::Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST)}}
–neural, vascular tumours
–Lymphoma
•{{c1::Inflammatory }}
–e.g. chronic inflammatory bowel disease; rectal prolapse
•{{c1::Hamartomas}}

Hyperplastic Polyps (HP)
  • Very common
  • Most in {{c1::recto-sigmoid}} region
  • Usually <0.5 cm
  • {{c1::Asymptomatic:: symptomatic/asymptomatic}}
  • Composed of hyperplastic mucosa
  • Malignant potential {{c1::rare:: rare/common}}
In the histology, you can observe {{c1::hyperplastic}} epithelium - columns. Small {{c1::infoldings}} into the lumen of the gland and {{c1::crypts}} due to increased number of cells lining that gland. The {{c1::hyperplastic}} mucosa is causing {{c1::infoldings}} within the crypt that is responsible for the bulge seen in red image (no malignant potential). 


hyperplastic polpyps

Sessile Serrated Lesion (SSL)

-Type of  {{c1::hyperplastic polyp}}
•Usually in {{c1::right}} side of colon
•Diagnosed on morphology;
    • {{c1::Asymmetric}} architecture at base of crypt: 
      {{c1::boot }} shaped; inverted T
•{{c1::Serrated}} appearance of crypts
•No dysplasia in a SSL (but dysplasia arise in an SSL: ‘SSL with dysplasia’)
•Links to MSI high sporadic (MSI high) carcinomas justifies distinguishing SSL from usual HPs
no dysplasia - but dysplasia can be superimposed on it

Adenomas

Common
•{{c1::Middle}} age adults
•{{c1::Left}} side more common than {{c1::right}} side
•Usually form a {{c1::polyp}}
•Classified acc. to {{c1::growth}} pattern:
    –Tubular (pedunculated) 
    – {{c1::Sessile}}
    –{{c1::‘Flat’}} adenomas are uncommon
•Have {{c1::dysplastic}} epithelium by definition (low vs high grade)


This image is of a {{c1::tubular}} adenoma.


This image is of a {{c1::pedunculated}} adenoma with a stalk.


This image is of a {{c1::villous (sessile)}} adenoma.

Risk of Progression to Malignancy 

•Size of adenoma
   –Cancer rare in adenoma < {{c1::10}} mm
   –{{c1::40}}% adenomas > 40 mm have a cancer
•% of villous growth
    –{{c1::Tubulovillous}} > 20%
    –Villous: >80%
•Presence of high grade {{c1::dysplasia}}
•Number of adenomas

Management of Adenomas
•Tubular Adenomas are removed during {{c1::colonoscopy}}
•High-grade dysplasia (HGD) or invasion in adenoma necessitates ‘complete’ {{c1::excision}} with clear margins
•VAs may require {{c1::surgery}} if  large as it can be difficult to excise a VA and obtain clear margins

Hamartomas

•Uncommon
•Can occur {{c1::anywhere}} in GIT
•Can be solitary
•Also occur as part of different syndromes
e.g. {{c1::Peutz jeghers}} or 
Cowden, Cronkite 
Canada Syndrome,
{{c1::Tuberous sclerosis}}




Can get massively expanded glands due to the {{c1::hyperplasia}} arranged in a strange way.

hamartoma can be hyperplastic or neoplastic. They consist of tissue native to the site arranged in a very disorganized way. 
  • Can get massively expanded glands bc of hyperplasia arranged in a strange way. Splaying of mucosa. Muscularis mucosa moving into lamina propria where it shouldn’t be.

Symptoms of a polyp or mass in colon

•{{c1::Asymptomatic}}
•Frank bleeding 
    •Especially for large or left-sided lesion
•{{c1::Occult}} bleeding 
•Detected by screening
•{{c1::Anemia}}
•Altered {{c1::bowel}} habit
•Obstruction 
•Metabolic e.g. {{c1::hypokalemia}}
•Rarely, intussusception

Intussusception
 Can occur with any type of mass
•{{c1::Fixes}} one part of the colon
•{{c1::Telescopes}} an adjacent portion of the colon
•Causes {{c1::obstruction}}

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

- AD (Autosomal dominant)
–Inactivating mutation in {{c1::APC}} gene (adenomatous polyposis coli) ch5 which is a {{c1::Tumour suppressor}} gene.
–>>100 adenomas in large bowel 
–Also in SB, stomach
–Without colectomy, {{c1::100}}% progress to colorectal carcinoma 
–Extra-GI manifestations are also present (bone tumours, problems with retina..)
     •Cancer and non-cancer

Other Polyposis syndromes

Adenomas
•{{c1::Gardner}}
•Turcot 
•{{c1::Attenuated}} FAP
•MYH-associated polyposis (AR)

Hamatomatous (hallmark is lots of {{c1::hamartomas}})
•{{c1::Peutz-Jeghers}}
      –STK11
•Juvenile Polyposis
      –SMAD, TGFbpathway

Colorectal Carcinoma: Risk factors 

•Peak 60-70s
•US, Canada ++
•Diet: High {{c1::caloric}} diet, high {{c1::fat}} and refined carbohydrate intake and low {{c1::vegetable and fibre:: 2 words}} intake
•Low intake of vitamin A, E, C
•{{c1::Smoking}}
•{{c1::Aspirin}} shown to be protective  (Nurses Health Study)
•Sporadic {{c1::adenomas}}/Hx of removal of polyps

Carcinoma and CIBD
•Risk in long-standing UC with {{c1::pancolitis}}
•Overall incidence is {{c1::low}}
•Symptoms masked by underlying {{c1::disease}}
•Multiple carcinomas without obvious {{c1::mass}}
•Mechanism not entirely clear (?oxidative stress)

Family History 

•Risk of developing CRC increased {{c1::2-3}} fold in 1st degree relatives of CRC patients
•Number of  affected {{c1::relatives}} important
•3-4 fold increase in risk with > {{c1::1}} family member affected
•Age of  onset  of cancer in {{c1::index}} case is important
•RR {{c1::3.9}} if cancer diagnosed aged 45-59

Think of Hereditary CRC when
•There is a strong {{c1::family}} history
•The onset is at a {{c1::young}} age  
•Large numbers of {{c1::polyps}} are found (polyposis syndromes)
•Cancers are identified in different sites (GI and non-GI) including in family members
•Non-neoplastic extra-{{c1::GIT}} features are present

2 pathways that drive colonic neoplasia
1. {{c1::Chromosomal instability (CIN)}} pathway
2. {{c1::Microsatellite instability (MSI)}} pathway (Hereditary (Lynch) and Sporadic methylation)

Chromosomal instability (CIN) pathway

•Vogelstein Model of {{c1::Cancer}}
•Mechanism for cancers in {{c1::FAP}} and in 80% sporadic carcinomas
•Tumours  with CIN show {{c1::aneuploidy}} and {{c1::chromosome}} loss 
•CIN is an effective way of causing loss of a wild type allele of {{c1::TSG }}

CIN (APC) Pathway involves the stepwise accumulation of genetic aberrations that correlate with a morphological progression from normal mucosa to {{c1::adenomas}} to {{c1::carcinomas}} (This is the {{c1::adenoma-carcinoma}} sequence). The {{c1::number}} of mutations are more important than the sequence (4-5 molecular events in key pathways necessary).



1. {{c1::APC}}
2. {{c1::RAS}}
3. {{c1::Carcinoma}}

Risk of progression to malignancy

In clinical practice, we rely on adenoma {{c1::size}}, presence of high grade {{c1::dysplasia}}, % {{c1::villosity}} and number of {{c1::polyps}} to estimate the risk of progression to malignancy
–Cancer rare in adenoma < 10 mm
–40% of adenomas > {{c1::4}} cm have a cancer

Microsatellite instability (MSI) pathway

•Involves cancers arising in {{c1::HNPCC/Lynch Family}} Syndrome and 10-15% sporadic cancers 

•HNPCC/Lynch Family Syndrome
–{{c1::AD}} (autosomal ...)
–Mutations in DNA {{c1::MMR}} genes
–{{c1::80}}% lifetime risk of CRC
–Onset at {{c1::45}} years
–Rapid growth 
–{{c1::Right::Right/Left}} side (Multiple tumours, mucinous subtype)
–Also carcinoma of small bowel & endometrium

Classic presentation: right-sided carcinoma
  • {{c1::Fatigue}}
  • {{c1::Pallor}}, pale conjunctiva
  • {{c1::Iron def}} anaemia
  • Vague mass in RIF
  • •±Altered {{c1::bowel}} habit

Classic Presentation: left-sided tumour
  • Altered {{c1::bowel}} habit  –Constipation/diarrhoea
  • {{c1::PR}} bleeding
  • ±abdominal {{c1::pain}}
  • ±LIF mass
*PR - post rectal?
